content: Hola, Hasta ahora no había escuchado de ese problema, al seleccionar un nombre de perfil solo se debería borrar esa carpeta, el sistema es el mismo tanto para Firefox como para Thunderbird por eso me resulta raro este problema. Con respecto a los archivos borrados cuando los encuentras con una aplicación de recuperación debes recuperar los archivos en el momento porque al borrar un archivo este "se marca" como borrado permitiendo que su espacio pueda ser utilizado por otros archivos, por lo tanto solo esta un tiempo limitado marcado como borrado, cuanto mas uses la PC mas probable que el archivo se pierda definitivamente. También es recomendable utilizar cuentas IMAP ya que permite que los correos sean almacenados en el servidor y ademas hacer frecuentes respaldo de las carpetas de perfil del TB. Saludos

content:
After you click Write, the composition panel opens, with buttons along (near) the top. If Send is not there, right-click just beside any buttons that DO show up, and choose Customize. That will open a panel with a bunch of icons in it. Look around until you find Send, then click on it, hold your mouse button down, and drag that Send icon to the line of other buttons already there. A "No Entry" icon will show up as you drag the Send icon, and when you get to a place where it can be dropped, that red signal will disappear, and you can drop the Send icon at that point.

Please come back and tell us whether you succeeded at this.

creator: valentin.brasov

content:
Visit the website of your email provider (e.g., Gmail, Yahoo, Outlook). Look for a "Sign In" or "Login" option on their website and click on it. On the sign-in page, look for a "Forgot Password," "Reset Password," or similar option. Click on it. You might be asked to provide your email address or username associated with the account. Enter the required information. Depending on your email provider, you'll receive password reset instructions via an alternative email address, a mobile phone number, or you might be prompted to answer security questions. Follow the instructions provided by your email provider to reset your password. Once you've reset your password, open Thunderbird and update the password for your email account in Thunderbird's account settings. To do this, go to "Tools" (or "Options") > "Account Settings" > select your email account > update the password field. Save the changes, and Thunderbird should now use your new password to access your email account.

Regards, TG
creator: techguy150

content:
Each account is considered independent and therefore you set up all those settings for each account prior to use. For example all pop accounts will use the same set of folders for eg: Sent emails - the 'Sent' folder, but imap accounts may vary as some call the sent storage 'Sent Mail' or 'Sent Items' or 'Sent' etc, so it would need checking on a per account basis.

The adaptive junk controls are enabled by default because most people want to sort junk. The adaptive junk controls need to be trained, so that Thunderbird knows what is Junk and what is not Junk. So it is advantageous to say what is not junk just as much as saying what is junk. There is only one set of training data, so if you decide to reset it then it does get applied to all accounts.

Helpful links. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages http://kb.mozillazine.org/Junk_Mail_Controls

Imap accounts offer more configurations eg: full download or headers and this can be set up on a per folder basis and also the extent of sycnronisation, full or partial. Thunderbird sets a basic default to enable full download on default server folders and allows the user to adapt as required.

composition and editing - most people choose to compose using HTML so it is set as default, but as ane xample, I do have one account which I've set plain text as default. Please note what ever you set as default, it can be altered on the fly by holding down 'Shift' key and pressing 'Write' button and whatever you have set as default the result will be the opposite.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I'm asking about the settings on:

  • Copies and folders
  • Composition & Addressing
  • Junk Settings
  • Synchronization & Storage

For example, adaptive junk controls are enabled by default in every new mail account. So right when I was starting with Thunderbird and trying to figure everything out, it was moving some valid emails to the Junk folder without giving me a clue.

Having that be the default is an issue for the suggestion box, not here. But once I figured it out, at least I could disable it for any new email accounts while Thunderbird built up some experience.
creator: Toolworker

content:
Specifically what default settings are you talking about?

When creating a new > existing mail account for an email address, Thunderbird will try to configure the server settings and by default tries to set up an IMAP account. However, at this point you can alter the settings by changing the Protocol to Pop and then check the server settings are correct before clicking on 'Done'.

Alternative - after entering name, email address and password - You can click on 'Configure Manually' button which offers you the ability to enter server settings. This is likely to be more useful if you are not using one of the main servers eg: maybe if you have your own website and domain for emails.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you're encountering an empty Thunderbird window when you open the application, it could be caused by various factors. Here are some troubleshooting steps to try:

Check for a hidden window: Sometimes, Thunderbird may open but be positioned off-screen or minimized. Look for Thunderbird in the taskbar or system tray, right-click on it, and select "Maximize" or "Restore" to bring the window back into view.

Restart Thunderbird: Close Thunderbird completely and then relaunch it. Sometimes, a temporary glitch can cause the window to appear empty, and restarting the application can resolve the issue.

Disable hardware acceleration: Thunderbird uses hardware acceleration to enhance its performance, but it can sometimes cause display issues. To disable hardware acceleration, go to "Tools" (or "Options") > "Options" > "Advanced" > "General" > "Config Editor." Search for the preference "gfx.direct2d.disabled" and set it to "true." Restart Thunderbird and check if the window appears correctly.

Clear Thunderbird profile cache: The Thunderbird profile cache can sometimes become corrupted and cause display problems. To clear the cache, close Thunderbird completely, press "Win + R" to open the Run dialog, type "%appdata%" (without quotes), and press Enter. Locate the Thunderbird folder, open it, and find the "Profiles" folder. Rename the "Profiles" folder to "Profiles.old" to create a backup. Then, relaunch Thunderbird, and it will create a new profile. Check if the window is no longer empty.
creator: techguy150
